Friends of the Earth, a Washington-based environmental group, is at it again in its role as guardian of the earth's ozone shield.

Earlier in 1987 the group persuaded a number of fast-food chains to stop using foam packaging that is made with chlorofluorocarbons. Those are the chemicals that are widely believed to be depleting the atmospheric ozone that protects the earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

Now the organization is challenging the nation's hospitals to stop using the chemicals for the sterilization of surgical equipment. The group says that hospitals account for about 3 percent of all chlorofluorocarbon consumption in the United States and that efficient substitutes are readily available.

In a letter to Carol McCarthy, president of the American Hospital Association, Friends of the Earth called on the association ''to take a leadership role in ending hospital use of these dangerous compounds.''
''Please ask your members to cease using chemicals which are destroying the ozone layer and join the campaign to protect the fragile chemistry of our atmosphere,'' the letter said.
